choices.text: Ependymoma
Medulloblastoma
Oligodendroglioma
Glioblastoma

questions.text: In reviewing brain imaging studies of various neoplasms, a physician notes the frequent occurrence of intratumoral calcifications. Such calcifications, though not exclusive, are most characteristically associated with which of the following types of primary brain tumors?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oligodendroglioma

 

Option C:

 

Oligodendrogliomas are tumors derived from oligodendrocytes, a type of glial cell. They are known to undergo calcification, and this calcification can be visualized on imaging studies. Oligodendrogliomas are relatively slow-growing tumors and are more commonly observed in adults.

 

The other three tumors in the options namely ependymoma, medulloblastoma and glioblastoma do not undergo calcification that frequently.

 

Oligodendrogliomas are glial cell tumors with a propensity for calcification, often seen on imaging studies, and this feature can aid in their diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Ependymomas, tumors arising from ependymal cells lining the ventricular system, can have various imaging features, but they are not specifically known for frequent calcification.

 

Option B: Medulloblastomas, which are malignant childhood tumors of the cerebellum, may show calcification, but it is not as common or pronounced as in oligodendrogliomas.

 

Option D: Glioblastomas are highly aggressive brain tumors that may occasionally show areas of calcification; however, calcifications are more characteristic and frequent in oligodendrogliomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oligodendroglioma is the tumor most commonly associated with calcification in adult patients, a feature that can be visualized on imaging studies.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1295

choices.text: Meningioma
Hemangioma
Glioma

questions.text: Verocay bodies are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Schwannoma

 

Option D:

 

  • Schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that abut the associated nerve without invading it. Microscopically, they are comprised of an admixture of dense and loose areas referred to as Antoni A and Antoni B areas, respectively.
  • The dense eosinophilic Antoni A areas often contain spindle cells arranged into cellular intersecting fascicles. Palisading of nuclei is common and “nuclear-free zones” that lie between the regions of nuclear palisading are termed Verocay bodies. In the loose, hypocellular Antoni B areas the spindle cells are spread apart by a prominent myxoid extracellular matrix that may be associated with microcyst formation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Meningiomas may exhibit whorled patterns and psammoma bodies, Verocay bodies are not a feature of meningiomas.

 

Option B: Hemangiomas are benign tumors derived from blood vessels and can occur in various tissues including the skin and internal organs. They do not display Verocay bodies.

 

Option C: Gliomas are tumors arising from glial cells in the central nervous system, including astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and ependymal cells. They do not have Verocay bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Verocay bodies are seen in schwannomas and are characterized by palisading nuclei creating nuclear-free zones within the densely cellular Antoni A areas of the tumor.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1302

choices.text: Pilocytic astrocytoma
Glioblastoma
Medulloblastoma
Ependymoma

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents with headaches and ataxia. Imaging reveals a cerebellar tumor with characteristic histological features, including the presence of eosinophilic, corkscrew-shaped protein aggregates known as Rosenthal fibers. Which of the following tumors is most likely responsible for these histopathological findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pilocytic astrocytoma

 

Option A:

 

Pilocytic astrocytomas are low-grade gliomas that commonly occur in the cerebellum of children and young adults. These tumors are characterized by the presence of Rosenthal fibers, which are eosinophilic, corkscrew-shaped protein aggregates.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Glioblastomas are high-grade tumors that can have various cellular morphologies but do not typically have Rosenthal fibers as a defining characteristic.

 

Option C: Medulloblastomas are highly malignant primitive neuroectodermal tumors commonly found in the cerebellum of children but are not associated with Rosenthal fibers.

 

Option D: Ependymomas arise from the ependymal cells of the ventricular system and can occur in the cerebellum, but they are not characterized by the presence of Rosenthal fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pilocytic astrocytoma is most likely responsible for the histopathological findings of eosinophilic, corkscrew-shaped Rosenthal fibers.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1293

choices.text: Lung
Liver
Spleen
CNS

questions.text: In a pediatric patient diagnosed with a primitive neuroectodermal tumor of the cerebellum (medulloblastoma) , known for its aggressive nature and potential for metastasis, which anatomical site would be the most vigilant for the detection of metastatic spread?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CNS

 

Option D:

 

Medulloblastomas have a propensity to spread to the subarachnoid space. Dissemination through the CSF is a common complication, giving rise to either extensive growth along the surface likened to “icing,” or nodular “drop metastases,” which tend to involve the cauda equina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medulloblastoma most commonly metastasizes within the central nervous system (CNS) , spreading through the CSF to create "drop metastases" particularly at the cauda equina.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1298

choices.text: Medulla
Cerebellum
Cerebrum
Pineal gland

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with symptoms of vomiting, headache, and unsteady gait. Brain imaging reveals the diagnosis of a medulloblastoma. Which of the following is the commonest for this tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cerebellum

 

Option B:

 

Key points about medulloblastoma

 

  • In children, the location is in the midline of the cerebellum, but lateral locations are more often found in adults.
  • Medulloblastomas are the most common malignant brain tumor of childhood
  • 5% of children have it in association with Gorlin syndrome (the most common of the inherited disorders due to mutations in the patched-1; PTCH-1 gene.
  • Histologically, there is presence of Homer-Wright rosettes.

 

Educational objective:

 

Medulloblastoma commonly occurs in the cerebellum , and is the most common malignant brain tumor of childhood.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1298

choices.text: Alzheimer disease
Parkinson disease
Huntington disease
Pick disease

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with gait problems. On examination, a key pathological feature in the substantia nigra neurons is observed, characterized by abnormal protein aggregates primarily composed of alpha-synuclein. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for the presence of these intracellular inclusions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parkinson disease

 

Option B:

 

Lewy bodies are abnormal protein aggregates primarily composed of alpha-synuclein. They are commonly found in the substantia nigra neurons in Parkinson's disease, contributing to the neurodegenerative process. These intracellular inclusions are a hallmark of Parkinson's disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: While Alzheimer's disease may involve abnormal protein aggregates, including beta-amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, Lewy bodies are not characteristic of Alzheimer's disease.

 

Option C: Huntington's disease is characterized by the presence of huntingtin protein aggregates but not Lewy bodies.

 

Option D: Pick's disease is associated with frontotemporal lobar degeneration and is characterized by Pick bodies, not Lewy bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parkinson disease is most likely responsible for the presence of these intracellular inclusions, as Lewy bodies composed of alpha-synuclein are a hallmark of this condition.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1282

questions.text: Which of the following is affected in patients with Alzheimer’s disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Temporal and Parietal lobe

 

Option B:

 

  • Grossly, the brain shows a variable degree of cortical atrophy marked by widening of the cerebral sulci that is most pronounced in the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes.
  • Hippocampus and other medial temporal lobe structures are the earliest and most severely affected in Alzheimer’s disease.
  • Bradley’s Neurology mentions that.. “cortical atrophy is most pronounced in the temporal and parietal lobe with the frontal lobe involvement being later in the disease”.
  • The parietal and temporal lobes are the areas most prominently affected in Alzheimer’s disease. The hippocampus, located in the medial temporal lobe, is particularly known for showing early atrophy.
  • Temporal lobe: especially the hippocampus: Involved in memory formation and learning. Early Alzheimer’s often presents with short-term memory loss due to hippocampal involvement.
  • Parietal lobe: Involved in spatial orientation, language, and navigation. As the disease progresses, patients may show visuospatial deficits and language disturbances.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: While the parietal and frontal lobes may be affected later in Alzheimer’s disease, they are not typically the regions most affected early in the disease process.

 

Option C: Temporal lobe involvement is a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease, but the occipital lobe is generally spared until the later stages of the disease.

 

Option D: The occipital lobe, involved in visual processing, is typically less affected than the parietal and temporal lobes in Alzheimer’s disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Alzheimer’s disease, atrophy is most pronounced in the parietal and temporal lobes, which includes the hippocampus, one of the earliest and most severely affected areas.

 

Ref: Robbin 10th/ 1275

choices.text: Syncytial
Fibroblastic
Anaplastic
Atypical

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with a history of progressively worsening headaches and focal neurological deficits. Brain imaging reveals an enhancing mass which on histopathological examination confirms the diagnosis of meningioma. Which subtype of meningioma is associated with the worst prognosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anaplastic

 

Option C:

 

Meningiomas are classified into different subtypes based on their histological features. Among these, anaplastic meningiomas have the worst prognosis. Anaplastic meningiomas are characterized by a higher degree of cellular atypia and increased mitotic activity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Syncytial meningiomas are characterized by densely packed cells with minimal intervening connective tissue.

 

Option B: Fibroblastic meningiomas are composed of spindle-shaped cells resembling fibroblasts.

 

Option D: Atypical meningiomas are intermediate in terms of aggressiveness between benign and anaplastic meningiomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaplastic meningioma is associated with the worst prognosis among the meningioma subtypes due to its high degree of cellular atypia and increased mitotic activity.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /1301

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with a resting tremor, bradykinesia, and rigidity. On examination, there is a characteristic "pill-rolling" tremor observed. The patient also exhibits postural instability. Which neurotransmitter is primarily affected in the pathophysiology of Parkinson's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dopamine

 

Option D:

 

Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. The loss of dopamine-producing neurons leads to the classic motor symptoms of resting tremor, bradykinesia, and rigidity. The characteristic "pill-rolling" tremor is often observed, and postural instability may develop as the disease progresses.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Changes in serotonin levels are more associated with mood disorders.

 

Option B: While imbalances in acetylcholine and dopamine play a role in movement disorders, the primary deficit in Parkinson's disease is related to dopamine deficiency.

 

Option C: GABA is an inhibitory neurotransmitter, and alterations in GABAergic transmission are not the primary cause of Parkinson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The neurotransmitter primarily affected in the pathophysiology of Parkinson's disease is Dopamine, which is depleted due to degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra, leading to characteristic symptoms like resting tremor, bradykinesia, and rigidity.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1293

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with neurological symptoms, and imaging reveals multiple intracranial lesions. Considering all tumor types, which is the most common cause of intracranial tumors in adults?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Secondaries

 

Option D:

 

Brain metastases or secondaries, which represent tumors that have spread to the brain from other organs, can collectively be a significant cause of intracranial tumors, especially in adults.

 

Secondary brain tumors, also known as metastatic brain tumors or secondaries, occur when cancer cells spread to the brain from another organ. These are the most common cause of intracranial tumors in adults, surpassing primary brain tumors in incidence.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Astrocytoma, which includes glioblastoma multiforme, is a type of primary brain tumor originating from astrocytes. They are one of the most common primary brain tumors in adults but not the most common cause of intracranial tumors when all tumor types are considered.

 

Option B: Medulloblastoma is a common brain tumor in children and is rarely the cause of intracranial tumors in adults, as its occurrence decreases significantly with age.

 

Option C: Meningiomas are common, usually benign, primary brain tumors arising from the meninges and are more prevalent in adults, particularly in women. However, they are not the most common cause of all intracranial tumors in adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secondaries are the most common cause of intracranial tumors in adults, with metastases to the brain from other primary cancers occurring more frequently than primary brain tumors.
  • Common primaries that metastasize to the brain: lung, breast, melanoma, kidney, and colon.
  • Often multiple lesions, located at the gray-white matter junction.
  • Account for 40–50% of intracranial tumors in adults.
  • Among primary brain tumors in adults:
    • Most common benign → Meningioma
    • Most common malignant → Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM, an astrocytoma subtype)

choices.text: Spreads through CSF
Surgical treatment not done
Occurs in young age group

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about medulloblastoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Surgical treatment not done

 

Option C:

 

Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumor that primarily affects the cerebellum and is more common in children. Surgical intervention is a crucial component of the management of this tumor and is performed to remove as much of the tumor as possible.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Medulloblastoma is a radiosensitive tumor and radiation therapy is often part of the treatment plan.

 

Option B: Medulloblastoma commonly spreads through the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), leading to leptomeningeal dissemination.

 

Option D: Medulloblastoma predominantly occurs in the pediatric age group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgical treatment is indeed performed for medulloblastoma and it is an important part of the management strategy for this type of tumor.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 1298

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman complains of increased fatigue since last 2 years. Her serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen are raised. USG shows both kidneys symmetrically reduced in size. Kidney biopsy done shows the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Systemic hypertension

 

This is hyaline arteriosclerosis of vessel wall seen in benign hypertension wherein the kidneys are symmetrically contracted.

 

Similar changes can also be seen in diabetes mellitus.

 

Option B:

 

In systemic hypertension, especially long-standing and poorly controlled cases, hyaline arteriosclerosis of the vessel wall can occur, leading to symmetrically reduced kidney size. This finding is consistent with the patient’s presentation and biopsy results.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Polyarteritis nodosa typically presents with vasculitis and fibrinoid necrosis on kidney biopsy. It is characterized by segmental necrotizing inflammation of medium-sized arteries, which would be evident on histological examination.

 

Option C: Malignant hypertension typically presents with "flea-bitten" kidneys on imaging and demonstrates fibrinoid necrosis on kidney biopsy. This patient's presentation, including symmetrically reduced kidney size and the absence of fibrinoid necrosis, is not consistent with malignant hypertension.

 

Option D: Wegener's granulomatosis is characterized by granulomatous inflammation of the vessel wall. However, the histological findings described in the patient's kidney biopsy do not align with this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Symmetrically reduced kidney size with hyaline arteriosclerosis of the vessel wall is indicative of systemic hypertension.

 

Onion-skinning of blood vessels in kidney is seen in:

 

  • Malignant hypertension
  • Chronic transplant rejection
  • Thrombotic microangiopathies (e.g., HUS, TTP)

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ p492)

questions.text: Which of the following is the commonest histological finding in benign hypertension?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyaline arteriolosclerosis

 

Option C:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Proliferative endarteritis is not the most common finding in benign hypertension. It involves inflammation and hyperplasia of the intima (inner layer) of arteries, often seen in conditions like vasculitis.

 

Option B. Necrotizing arteriolitis involves necrosis of the arterioles, and while it can occur in severe forms of hypertension, it is not the most common histological finding in benign hypertension.

 

Option D. Cystic medial necrosis is associated with conditions like Marfan syndrome and is characterized by degeneration and cystic changes in the arterial media. It is not a common finding in benign hypertension.

 

Educational objective:

 

The commonest histological finding in benign hypertension is Hyaline arteriolosclerosis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ p492)

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient comes to the clinic with concerns of difficulty in using her right arm, especially when performing tasks like combing her hair or reaching for objects on high shelves. She also reports occasional dizziness and headaches. On examination, you notice a significant difference in blood pressure between her arms, with the right arm showing a considerably lower reading. Additionally, the patient's right radial pulse is weak compared to the left. Fundoscopic examination reveals retinal hemorrhages. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Takayasu arteritis

 

Takayasu arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis of medium- and large-sized arteries particularly affecting the aorta and its main branches. This condition is more common in young women. Its clinical features may include diminished or absent pulses, particularly in the upper extremities. This is due to inflammation and stenosis of the large vessels, leading to reduced blood flow. Ocular involvement, including retinal hemorrhages, can be a manifestation of Takayasu arteritis. The inflammation and narrowing of the vessels can affect blood flow to various organs, including the eyes.

 

Option A:

 

Takayasu arteritis is a characterized princi­pally by ocular disturbances and marked weakening of the pulses in the upper extremities (hence the alternate name, pulseless disease)…Robbins

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Giant cell arteritis typically affects older individuals and involves inflammation of medium to large-sized arteries. It commonly presents with headaches, jaw claudication, and visual disturbances but is less associated with reduced pulses.

 

Option C: Microscopic polyangiitis is a small-vessel vasculitis. It often presents with renal involvement, lung disease, and skin manifestations. It is less likely to cause the characteristic findings of reduced pulses and retinal hemorrhages seen in the scenario.

 

Option D: Temporal arteritis, also known as giant cell arteritis when involving large vessels, is characterized by inflammation of medium to large arteries. While it can affect the upper limb arteries, it is more closely associated with the temporal arteries and often presents with headaches, jaw claudication, and visual disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical features of Takayasu arteritis includes reduced pulses in the upper limbs and retinal hemorrhages.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 385)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male smoker with a history of hypertension presents with mild abdominal discomfort and is found to have a pulsatile mass on abdominal examination. His blood pressure is well-controlled on antihypertensive medication. Which of the following is the most common cause of abdominal aortic aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atherosclerosis

 

Direct quote from Harrison….’atleast 90% of all abdominal aortic aneurysms >4.0 cm are related to atherosclerotic disease and most are present just below the renal arteries’.

 

Option A:

 

The predominant cause of AAA  is atherosclerosis, a condition characterized by the build-up of fatty deposits, cholesterol, and other substances on the walls of arteries. Over time, this leads to the formation of plaques that can weaken and damage the arterial walls.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: While syphilis can cause aortic aneurysms, it is less common in contemporary medicine due to the widespread use of antibiotics. Atherosclerosis is a more prevalent and frequent cause.

 

Option C: Trauma can indeed lead to aortic aneurysms, but it's generally less common than atherosclerosis as a cause. Traumatic aneurysms often result from severe injuries or accidents.

 

Option D: Congenital factors can contribute to the development of aortic aneurysms, but they are less common compared to acquired conditions. Atherosclerosis is still a more prevalent cause in the adult population.

 

Educational objective:

 

The predominant cause of abdominal aortic aneurysm is atherosclerosis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 509)

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a month-long history of malaise, weight loss, and renal impairment. His urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria and proteinuria. A chest X-ray reveals bilateral nodular infiltrates. Serology tests are positive for p-ANCA. Small vessels vasculitis is seen in
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Microscopic polyangiitis

 

Option D:

 

Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is a type of small-vessel vasculitis. It is characterized by inflammation of small blood vessels, including capillaries, venules, and arterioles. MPA is often associated with the presence of antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) and primarily affects the kidneys and lungs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Giant Cell Arteritis: Giant cell arteritis is primarily a large- and medium-sized vessel vasculitis. It typically involves large arteries such as the temporal arteries.

 

Option B: Takayasu Arteritis: Takayasu arteritis is a large-vessel vasculitis that affects the aorta and its major branches. It usually involves the large vessels rather than the small vessels.

 

Option C: Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN): Polyarteritis nodosa is a medium-sized vessel vasculitis that affects multiple organs. It is not typically considered a small-vessel vasculitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

This condition is a small-vessel vasculitis commonly associated with p-ANCA, involving the kidneys and lungs, which aligns with the patient's presentation of renal impairment, pulmonary nodules, and positive serology.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 513)

questions.text: A 5‑year‑old child presents with perivascular IgA deposition and neutrophilic collection. There is erythematous rash on the lower limbs and non-blanching purpura. The likely diagnosis in the child is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Henoch-Schonlein Purpura

 

Option A:

 

HSP is a small-vessel vasculitis that commonly occurs in children. It is characterized by perivascular IgA deposition, neutrophilic infiltration, and involvement of small blood vessels. Skin manifestations often include a rash on the lower limbs, which may be erythematous and have non-blanching purpura.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Wegener's Granulomatosis: Wegener's granulomatosis is a form of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), which primarily affects the upper and lower respiratory tracts and kidneys. It is not typically associated with IgA deposition.

 

Option C: Giant Cell Vasculitis: Giant cell vasculitis, such as giant cell arteritis, usually occurs in older individuals and involves large and medium-sized arteries. It is not commonly seen in children and does not present with the characteristic skin findings described.

 

Option D: Kawasaki's Disease: Kawasaki's disease is a vasculitis that affects medium-sized vessels, particularly the coronary arteries. While it can present with a rash, it is not associated with perivascular IgA deposition, which is a characteristic feature of HSP.

 

Educational objective:

 

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a small-vessel vasculitis that most commonly occurs in children and is characterized by a tetrad of palpable purpura, abdominal pain, arthralgia, and renal involvement. It is often preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection and is associated with IgA immune complex deposition in the affected vessels.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 561)

questions.text: In the evaluation of a patient with systemic vasculitis, which of the following conditions is least likely to show granulomatous inflammation on biopsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Microscopic polyangiitis

 

Option D: 

 

  • Microscopic polyangiitis does not involve granulomatous inflammation; rather, it is associated with necrotizing inflammation that affects small vessels.

  • It is MPO-ANCA positive vasculitis disorder, characterized by pauci-immune glomerulonephritis and pulmonary capillaritis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Wegener's granulomatosis, now referred to as Granulomatosis with polyangiitis is known for necrotizing granulomatous inflammation, particularly affecting the respiratory tract and the kidneys.

 

c-ANCA positive (PR3-ANCA)

 

Option B: Buerger’s disease is characterized by granulomatous inflammation of small- and medium-sized arteries and veins in the extremities, especially in smokers

 

Associated with segmental thrombosing vasculitis with microabscesses and granulomatous inflammation.

 

Option C: Takayasu’s arteritis exhibits granulomatous inflammation of large vessels, particularly the aorta and its major branches.

 

Granulomatous thickening of the vessel wall, often leading to "pulseless disease"

 

Educational Objective:

 

MPA is a type of small-vessel vasculitis associated with necrotizing inflammation without granuloma formation, distinguishing it from the other options that are characterized by granulomatous inflammation.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 513)

questions.text: Most common organs involved in Wegener’s granulo­matosis are:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lung and kidney

 

Explanation:

 

Wegener's granulomatosis, now known as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA), is characterized by necrotizing granulomatous inflammation affecting the respiratory tract (nose, sinuses, and lungs) and often the kidneys. It is associated with PR3-ANCA positivity, specifically against proteinase 3.

 

Educational objective:

 

Most common organs involved in Wegener’s granulo­matosis are lung and kidney.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 514)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with severe hypertension and worsening renal function is evaluated for suspected systemic vasculitis. She has a history of intermittent claudication and abdominal pain following meals. A biopsy of a medium-sized artery in her leg shows transmural inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis. Based on her clinical presentation, Polyarteritis nodosa does not involve:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pulmonary artery

 

Option A:

 

Polyarteritis nodosa typically does not involve the pulmonary arteries. It tends to affect arteries supplying various organs and tissues, but the pulmonary arteries are not commonly affected. 

 

Although large and muscular, pulmonary arteries are part of the pulmonary circulation, which is a low-pressure system distinct from the systemic arteries.

 

PAN is strictly a systemic vasculitis, the pulmonary arteries are consistently uninvolved. Therefore, option (a) is correct.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Polyarteritis nodosa can involve bronchial arteries. In fact, it can affect arteries throughout the body, including those supplying the respiratory system.

 

Option C: Polyarteritis nodosa commonly involves the renal arteries. Renal artery involvement can lead to renal ischemia and glomerulonephritis, which are characteristic features of PAN.

 

Option D: Polyarteritis nodosa typically does not commonly involve cerebral arteries. However, the best answer in the given question is pulmonary artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In polyarteritis nodosa, the pulmonary arteries are typically spared, which helps differentiate it from other systemic vasculitides that can involve the lungs.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th / 513)

questions.text: ANCA is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgA Vasculitis 

 

Option B: 

 

IgA Vasculitis is not typically associated with ANCA. It is an immune-mediated vasculitis that primarily affects small vessels and is often characterized by palpable purpura, abdominal pain, joint pain, and kidney involvement.

 

Antineutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibodies (ANCA) are autoantibodies that target components of neutrophils' cytoplasmic granules. ANCA-associated vasculitides (AAV) are a group of autoimmune diseases characterized by inflammation of small blood vessels. Among the options provided:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA): Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis is associated with PR 3ANCA (directed against proteinase 3), 

 

Option C. Microscopic polyangiitis: Microscopic polyangiitis is associated with MPO ANCA, directed against myeloperoxidase (MPO).

 

Option D. Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (EGPA):  Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis is associated with MPO ANCA directed against myeloperoxidase (MPO).

 

Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are not seen with IgA Vasculitis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 512)

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with high fever for five days, bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis, red cracked lips, a strawberry tongue, and swelling of the hands and feet. The child appears irritable, and his mother mentions a rash that developed over his trunk and extremities. Most dreadful complication of Kawasaki’s disease is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cardiac involvement

 

Kawasaki disease, It is a systemic vasculitis that primarily affects children. The classic features include prolonged fever, mucocutaneous involvement (such as the strawberry tongue and erythematous rash), and cervical lymphadenopathy. If untreated, Kawasaki disease can lead to coronary artery involvement and potentially serious complications.

 

Option C:

 

Cardiac involvement, specifically coronary artery aneurysms, is the most severe complication of Kawasaki disease and can have long-term cardiovascular implications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: While rash is a common feature of Kawasaki disease, it is not typically associated with the most serious complications.

 

Option B: Lymph node enlargement can be a feature of Kawasaki disease but is not considered the most severe complication.

 

Option D: Thrombocytosis is common in the second week of illness in Kawasaki disease and typically resolves; it is not the most feared complication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When treating Kawasaki disease, close monitoring for cardiac complications, such as coronary artery aneurysms, is critical due to the risk of serious outcomes like myocardial infarction or sudden death.

 

(Robbins 10th 512)

questions.text: Which laboratory test parameter can indicate the highest relative risk for developing atherosclerosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C- reactive protein

 

Option A:

 

C-reactive protein (CRP) is an inflammatory marker that when elevated, indicates endothelial cell activation and is associated with the development of atherosclerosis and cardiovascular risk.

 

  • C- reactive protein (CRP) is an acute phase reactant that causes endothelial cell activation, promote thrombosis and increases leukocyte adhesiveness in developing atheromas.

  • It is an independent predictor of CV risk.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Anti-proteinase 3 (PR3) is an antibody associated with vasculitis, specifically granulomatosis with polyangiitis, and is not a direct marker for atherosclerosis risk.

 

Option C: Cryoglobulins are immunoglobulins that precipitate in the cold and are associated with cryoglobulinemic vasculitis but are not direct indicators of atherosclerotic risk.

 

Option D: Platelet count can reflect thrombotic risk but is not an independent predictor of atherosclerosis or cardiovascular disease like CRP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRP is an acute-phase reactant that, when elevated, suggests systemic inflammation and is an independent risk factor for atherosclerosis and subsequent cardiovascular events.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not included as major criteria in Jones criteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Elevated ESR

 

The Jones criteria are used for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever. The major criteria include:

 

  1. Pancarditis

  2. Arthritis

  3. Subcutaneous nodules

  4. Sydenham chorea

  5. Erythema marginatum 

 

Option D:

 

Elevated ESR (Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate) is not a major criterion in the Jones criteria. While it can support the diagnosis of rheumatic fever as it indicates inflammation, it is not specific and is considered a minor criterion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Pancarditis is a major criterion in the Jones criteria. It encompasses inflammation of the entire heart, including the endocardium, myocardium, and pericardium.

 

Option B: Arthritis, specifically migratory polyarthritis, is a major criterion of the Jones criteria, typically affecting large joints.

 

Option C: Subcutaneous nodules are also a major criterion in the Jones criteria, though they are less common. They are firm, painless, and found over bones or tendons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Jones criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever include major criteria such as pancarditis, arthritis, subcutaneous nodules, Sydenham chorea, and erythema marginatum. Elevated ESR, while indicative of inflammation, is not a major criterion and is used as a minor or supportive criterion in the diagnosis of rheumatic fever.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 562)

questions.text: Most friable vegetation is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Infective endocarditis

 

Option A:

 

 

Educational objective:

 

The most friable vegetations, which are indicative of a high risk of embolization, are seen in infective endocarditis.

 

Friability refers to how easily a lesion breaks apart or embolizes. In cardiac vegetations, infective endocarditis (IE) is known to produce the most friable vegetations, due to their soft, necrotic, and loosely attached nature.

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 563)

questions.text: Aschoff bodies in rheumatic heart disease show all of the following features, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epithelioid cell

 

Option B:

 

Aschoff bodies consist of foci of swollen eosinophilic collagen surrounded by lymphocytes (primarily T cells), occasional plasma cells, and plump macrophages called Anitschkow cells (pathognomonic for rheumatic fever). These cells are also called “caterpillar cells”. Some of the larger macrophages become multinucleated to form Aschoff giant cells.

 

Epithelioid cells are characteristic of granulomatous inflammation, such as seen in tuberculosis or sarcoidosis, not in rheumatic fever.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Anitschkow cells are a hallmark of Aschoff bodies found in rheumatic heart disease. They are plump macrophages with a central round nucleus, giving a caterpillar-like appearance.

 

Option C: Giant cells, or Aschoff giant cells, result from the fusion of macrophages and are a feature of Aschoff bodies.

 

Option D: Fibrinoid necrosis is typically associated with several vasculitis as well as Rheumatic heart disease

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aschoff bodies, pathognomonic for rheumatic fever, consist of swollen eosinophilic collagen, T cells, occasional plasma cells, Anitschkow cells, and Aschoff giant cells. Epithelioid cells are not a feature of Aschoff bodies and are instead associated with granulomatous inflammation.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 561)

questions.text: In patients with a history of intravenous drug use, which heart valve is most commonly affected by infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tricuspid valve

 

Option D:

 

The most common heart valve involved in intravenous (IV) drug users is the tricuspid valve. Intravenous drug use can introduce bacteria into the bloodstream, leading to infections on heart valves. The tricuspid valve is particularly susceptible due to the direct flow of blood from the venous system into the right atrium and then the right ventricle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intravenous drug use predisposes individuals to infective endocarditis predominantly involving the tricuspid valve due to the direct flow of potentially infected blood from venous circulation to the right side of the heart.

 

Common Sites of Involvement in IE:

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 563)

questions.text: During autopsy of a patient died due to suspected myocardial infarction, the heart was stained with triphenyl tetrazolium tetra-chloride dye. What will be the color of the viable myocardium?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Brick red 

 

 

Option D:

 

This is the correct answer. Brick red coloration indicates viable myocardium when using TTC staining. Intact, noninfarcted myocardium contains enzymes like lactate dehydrogenase that reduce TTC to formazan, which has a brick-red color.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Blue is not the color associated with TTC staining. TTC is not a blue dye and does not produce a blue color in tissue staining.

 

Option B: White is the color that indicates an infarct on TTC staining because the enzyme activity necessary to convert TTC into a red dye is lost in the infarcted area due to cell death.

 

Option C: Yellow is not a typical result of TTC staining in either viable or non-viable myocardial tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In TTC staining during autopsy, viable myocardium is indicated by a brick-red color, which results from the presence of active dehydrogenase enzymes that reduce the TTC dye.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 546)

questions.text: Most common primary tumor of heart is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myxoma

 

Option A:

 

The most common primary tumor of the heart is a myxoma. Myxomas are typically benign tumors that most commonly arise in the atria of the heart. They are often found in the left atrium and can cause symptoms such as obstruction of blood flow, leading to issues like syncope and heart failure. Myxomas are composed of stellate or plump cells within a myxoid stroma.

 

Myxoma is indeed the most common primary tumor of the heart. These benign tumors are often found in the left atrium and can cause obstructive symptoms affecting blood flow.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a type of malignant soft tissue tumor that can occur in the heart, but it is not the most common primary cardiac tumor.

 

Option C: Fibroma is another type of benign cardiac tumor that typically occurs in children. While it can be found in the heart, it is not as common as myxoma.

 

Option D: Leiomyosarcoma is a malignant tumor of smooth muscle cells. It is rare in the heart and is not the most common primary cardiac tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common primary tumor of the heart is a myxoma, which is a benign growth that most commonly arises in the atria, particularly the left atrium, and can lead to symptoms related to blood flow obstruction.

 

 (Ref: Robbins 10th/579)

questions.text: What is the primary contributor to insulin resistance in liver disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Steatosis

 

Option B:

 

The accumulation of fat in the liver, or hepatic steatosis, is closely associated with insulin resistance. It impairs the liver's response to insulin, particularly affecting the inhibition of gluconeogenesis and increasing insulin resistance in peripheral tissues.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Decreased insulin release: This refers to a problem with insulin secretion from the pancreas, not resistance at the level of hepatic or peripheral tissues and does not directly relate to liver disease.

 

Option C: Hepatocyte dysfunction: While hepatocyte dysfunction can contribute to metabolic disturbances, it is a broader term that includes various liver impairments, not specific to insulin resistance.

 

Option D: Decreased ‘C’ peptide level: C-peptide is a byproduct of insulin production. Lower levels may indicate reduced insulin secretion but are not a direct cause of insulin resistance in the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatic steatosis, or fatty liver disease, is a significant contributor to insulin resistance, which impairs both the liver's response to insulin and the peripheral action of insulin.

 

Ref: Robbin 10th/ 1140, Joslin’s Diabetes Mellitus 14/e p436

questions.text: Most common association in MEN I is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gastrinoma

 

Option A:

 

Gastrinomas, which secrete gastrin, are among the most common functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with MEN I and can lead to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Insulinoma: Insulinomas are also associated with MEN I and result in hypoglycemia due to unregulated insulin secretion, but they are less common compared to gastrinomas.

 

Option C: Lipoma: While patients with MEN I may develop non-endocrine tumors like lipomas, these are not as commonly associated with the syndrome as endocrine tumors.

 

Option D: Glucagonoma: Glucagonomas, which secrete glucagon, are rare pancreatic endocrine tumors and are less commonly associated with MEN I than gastrinomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of MEN I, gastrinomas are the most commonly associated functional pancreatic endocrine tumors, often leading to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by peptic ulcer disease, gastroesophageal reflux, and diarrhea due to hypergastrinemia.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1140

choices.text: Most of them are malignant
C-peptide level is elevated
It is not associated with MEN 1 syndrome

questions.text: True about insulinoma is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C-peptide level is elevated

 

Option C:

 

This is correct. Insulinomas cause increased production of insulin, and because C-peptide is co-released with insulin, its levels are also elevated.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Alpha cell tumor: This is incorrect; insulinomas arise from beta cells of the pancreas, which are responsible for the production of insulin.

 

Option B: Most of them are malignant: The majority of insulinomas are benign; only a small percentage are malignant.

 

Option D: It is not associated with MEN 1 syndrome: This is incorrect; insulinomas can be associated with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulinomas are beta-cell tumors, most of which are benign and can present with hypoglycemia and elevated levels of insulin and C-peptide in the blood. They may also be associated with MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1124

questions.text: What marker is indicative of a non-functional pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor (PNET)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chromogranin-A

 

Option A:

 

Chromogranin A is a protein found in the secretory vesicles of neuroendocrine cells. It is a commonly used marker for PNETs, especially when they do not secrete hormones or their secretion is not clinically apparent.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: CD100: CD100 is not a recognized marker for PNETs. CD markers are generally used in the characterization of lymphocytes and other cells of the immune system.

 

Option C: CEA: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a tumor marker associated with colorectal cancer and some other adenocarcinomas, not specifically with PNETs.

 

Option D: PSA: Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is used as a marker for prostate cancer. It has no relevance in the diagnosis of PNETs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromogranin A is a marker for pancreatic non-functional neuroendocrine tumours.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 720

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of bilateral lower extremity swelling and fatigue for the past several months. He has a past medical history significant for poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and obesity. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum creatinine and proteinuria. A renal biopsy is performed, which demonstrates deposition of amyloid proteins in the glomeruli. Which of the following types of diabetes mellitus is most commonly associated with this renal complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type II DM

 

Option C:

 

Type II DM is associated with the deposition of amyloid in the pancreatic islets, contributing to β-cell dysfunction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Maturity onset diabetes of the young (MODY) is characterized by monogenic defects of β-cell function but is not typically associated with amyloid deposition in the islets.

 

Option B: Type I DM is an autoimmune disorder leading to β-cell destruction and does not typically involve amyloid deposition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amyloid deposition in the islets of Langerhans is a feature specifically associated with Type II diabetes mellitus, which can contribute to the dysfunction of insulin-secreting pancreatic β-cells.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 261

choices.text: Psammoma body present in 50% cases
Early metastasis with poor prognosis

questions.text: About papillary carcinoma of thyroid, all are true except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Early metastasis with poor prognosis

 

Option C:

 

Although papillary thyroid carcinoma can metastasize early, particularly to regional lymph nodes, it usually maintains a good prognosis and is often curable.

 

This does not worsen prognosis significantly.

 

Even with lymph node metastasis, survival remains excellent.

 

Distant metastasis (to lungs or bone) is rare, and when present, prognosis may be slightly worse but still much better than most other cancers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Associated with BRAF mutation: Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is associated with BRAF gene mutation.

 

Option B. Psammoma body present in 50% cases: Psammoma bodies are calcifications that are often found in papillary thyroid carcinoma but may not be present in as many as 50% of cases.

 

Option D. Spreads by the lymphatic route: This is true. Papillary thyroid carcinoma commonly spreads to regional lymph nodes via lymphatics.

 

This typically involves:

 

  • Cervical lymph nodes (neck)
  • Jugular lymph chain

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid typically has a favorable prognosis, even with early lymphatic spread, contrasting with other cancers where early metastasis often correlates with a poor prognosis.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1086

choices.text: Anemia of chronic disease

questions.text: A 51-year-old man Sonu with a history of recurrent calcium-containing renal stones presents to the emergency room with excruciating flank pain and blood in the urine. This patient is likely to have which of the following underlying disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperparathyroidism

 

Option C:

 

The patient’s history of recurrent urolithiasis with calcium containing stones implies a disorder in the regulation of calcium concentration. Hyperparathyroidism is associated with increased PTH levels, which can produce hypercalcemia, hypercalciuria, and, ultimately, renal stones.

 

Primary hyperparathyroidism leads to elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, resulting in increased bone resorption, hypercalcemia, and hypercalciuria, which can cause calcium-containing renal stones.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Anemia of chronic disease – This condition is associated with long-standing, chronic illnesses that lead to alterations in iron metabolism and erythropoiesis but is not directly related to calcium stone formation.

 

Option B: Chronic Proteus infection – While Proteus bacteria can increase the risk for struvite stone formation due to urease production, it is not typically associated with calcium stone formation.

 

Option D: Hyperaldosteronism – This condition leads to hypertension and hypokalemia due to excess aldosterone and is not typically associated with calcium-containing renal stone disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recurrent calcium-containing renal stones may suggest an underlying disorder of calcium metabolism, such as hyperparathyroidism, due to its association with increased PTH levels, hypercalcemia, and hypercalciuria.

 

Ref: Robbins 9/e p1103

questions.text: Fine needle aspiration cytology is not able to detect which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular cancer

 

Option C:

 

FNAC cannot differentiate between benign follicular adenomas and follicular carcinoma due to the requirement of histologic evaluation of the capsule for invasion, which is not possible with FNAC.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Papillary carcinoma: FNAC is usually diagnostic for papillary carcinoma due to its distinctive cytological features, including nuclear grooves and psammoma bodies.

 

Option B: Hashimoto thyroiditis: FNAC can suggest this diagnosis when lymphocytes and Hurthle cells are present, indicating an autoimmune process.

 

Option D: Medullary cancer: FNAC can suggest medullary carcinoma by demonstrating amyloid and calcitonin in cells, but a definitive diagnosis often requires additional tests such as serum calcitonin levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While FNAC is a useful tool in the initial assessment of thyroid nodules, it cannot distinguish between follicular adenoma and follicular carcinoma due to the necessity of examining capsular and vascular invasion histologically.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1089

questions.text: Most common thyroid cancer after radiation exposure is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Papillary cancer

 

Option A:

 

  • There is a marked increase in the incidence of papillary carcinomas among children exposed to ionizing radiation (particularly during the first 2 decades of life).
  • Deficiency of dietary iodine (and so, goiter) is linked with a higher frequency of follicular carcinomas.

 

Exposure to ionizing radiation, especially during the first two decades of life, significantly increases the risk of developing papillary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Medullary cancer: Medullary thyroid cancer arises from parafollicular C-cells and is typically associated with genetic mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, not with radiation exposure.

 

Option C: Follicular cancer: While not associated with radiation exposure, the incidence of follicular carcinoma is higher in areas with iodine deficiency.

 

Option D: Anaplastic cancer: Anaplastic thyroid cancer is a rare and aggressive form of thyroid cancer that generally occurs in the elderly population and is not associated with radiation exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid cancer associated with childhood exposure to ionizing radiation, which can significantly increase the risk of this cancer.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1086

questions.text: Orphan Annie eye nuclei appearance is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Papillary carcinoma thyroid

 

Option A:

 

This thyroid cancer is noted for its unique nuclear features, which include enlarged, overlapping nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin giving an "empty" appearance, also known as 'Orphan Annie eye' nuclei.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

'Orphan Annie eye' nuclei is a distinctive cytological feature of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, which is important for diagnosis and distinguishing it from other neoplasms.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1087

choices.text: Papillary carcinoma of thyroid

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents with a solitary thyroid nodule. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is performed, and the pathologist reports that the distinction between a benign and a malignant lesion cannot be made with certainty. Which type of thyroid nodule is most notorious for requiring histologic examination beyond FNAC to establish a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Follicular carcinoma of thyroid

 

Option D:

 

FNAC cannot distinguish between follicular adenoma and follicular carcinoma because the diagnosis of carcinoma depends on the identification of capsular and/or vascular invasion, which requires histologic examination of the surgical specimen.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Papillary carcinoma of thyroid: Papillary carcinoma typically shows distinctive nuclear features on FNAC which are usually diagnostic, making it sufficient for diagnosis.

 

Option B: Carcinoma breast: FNAC can be diagnostic for breast carcinoma, showing malignant cells, but a core biopsy is often preferred for additional architectural and immunohistochemical information.

 

Option C: Adenocarcinoma lung: While FNAC can suggest adenocarcinoma of the lung by demonstrating malignant glandular cells, a core biopsy is usually required for complete characterization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While FNAC can suggest follicular neoplasm, it cannot differentiate follicular carcinoma from follicular adenoma as the latter requires the identification of capsular or vascular invasion, which necessitates histological examination of the entire surgical specimen.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1089

choices.text: Pituitary tumor
Adrenal adenoma

questions.text: Most common cause of Cushing’s syndrome is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Exogenous corticosteroids

 

Option A:

 

The most frequent cause of Cushing's syndrome is the iatrogenic administration of exogenous corticosteroids. This can occur with prolonged use of oral, intravenous, or inhaled glucocorticoids for the treatment of various conditions such as asthma, autoimmune diseases, or after organ transplantation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: A pituitary adenoma that secretes adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) can cause Cushing's disease, which is a subset of Cushing's syndrome. This is the most common cause of endogenous Cushing's syndrome, but overall less common than the exogenous form caused by taking corticosteroid medications.

 

Option C: An adrenal adenoma is a benign tumor of the adrenal gland that can autonomously secrete cortisol. It's a less common cause of Cushing's syndrome compared to exogenous steroid use and pituitary tumors but should be considered, especially when ACTH levels are low.

 

Option D: Adrenal carcinomas are rare but can also cause Cushing's syndrome by secreting excessive amounts of cortisol. They are more aggressive than adenomas and can be associated with a worse prognosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exogenous corticosteroids are the most common cause of Cushing's syndrome, primarily due to the widespread use of corticosteroid medications for a variety of medical conditions.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1115

questions.text: Which of the following condition is associated with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gilbert syndrome

 

Option C:

 

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is characterized by elevated levels of unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin in the blood. Gilbert syndrome is a common inherited condition associated with mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It results from a decreased activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, leading to impaired conjugation of bilirubin in the liver.

 

Explanation

 

Option A: Dubin-Johnson syndrome: it is characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a rare genetic disorder where there is impaired excretion of conjugated bilirubin from the liver.

 

Option B: Rotor syndrome: it is also associated with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a benign condition characterized by elevated levels of both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin.

 

Option D: Gall stones:  they can lead to obstructive jaundice, causing elevated levels of both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin. However, the primary association is with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gilbert syndrome is a common inherited condition associated with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 853

questions.text: A 34-year-old man Bholu presents to his physician with loss of appetite, nausea and vomiting, and fatigue. Laboratory examination confirms the diagnosis of hepatitis B, and the man becomes icteric 2 weeks later. This patient may also be particularly vulnerable to the development of which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polyarteritis nodosa

 

Option C:

 

Thirty percent of patients with polyarteritis nodosa have hepatitis B antigenemia. Polyarteritis is a systemic necrotizing vasculitis that can be difficult to diagnose, since the vascular involvement is typically widely scattered, and the specific symptoms depend on the specific vessels (small-to medium-sized arteries) involved. Patients typically present with low-grade fever, weakness, and weight loss. Abdominal pain, hematuria, renal failure, hypertension, and leukocytosis may occur. The disease is frequently fatal if untreated.

 

Explanation

 

Option A: Berry aneurysm: A berry aneurysm is typically associated with conditions like polycystic kidney disease and hypertension, and it predominantly affects the cerebral vasculature. It is not commonly linked to hepatitis B infection.

 

Option B: Coronary artery aneurysm: This type of aneurysm is often associated with Kawasaki disease or atherosclerosis, and there is no direct link to hepatitis B infection for the development of coronary artery aneurysms.

 

Option D: Giant cell arteritis: Giant cell arteritis typically affects the large and medium arteries of older adults, particularly the temporal arteries, and is not associated with hepatitis B infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There is a well-established association between hepatitis B infection and the development of polyarteritis nodosa, a systemic necrotizing vasculitis that can affect various organ systems and can be fatal if untreated.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 510

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with Mallory hyaline bodies?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Secondary biliary cirrhosis

 

Option C:

 

  • Mallory bodies, also known as Mallory hyaline bodies or Mallory-Denk bodies, are abnormal intracellular inclusions found in hepatocytes. These structures are associated with various liver diseases, particularly those involving chronic hepatocellular injury. They are remembered as (New Indian Fine WATCH)

  • Non alcoholic fatty liver disease; NAFLD 

  • Indian childhood cirrhosis

  • Focal nodular hyperplasia

  • Wilson’s Disease

  • Alcoholic liver disease, α-1 AT def.

  • Tumor (HCC)

  • Cholestasis (due to primary biliary cirrhosis)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mallory-denk bodies (made up keratin 8 and 18) are associated with various liver diseases, particularly those involving chronic hepatocellular injury, but are not typically found in secondary biliary cirrhosis.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 843

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus and joint pains presents with skin hyperpigmentation and elevated serum ferritin. A liver biopsy is performed, and the resulting slide is shown. The patient's liver biopsy is notable for a blue staining pattern within the hepatocytes. Given below is the histopathology of liver biopsy of a patient with hemochromatosis. Which of the following stain has been used?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prussian blue

 

Option A:

 

This iron stain, also known as Perls' Prussian blue, detects ferric iron by turning it blue. It is specifically used for the detection of iron overload in tissues, as seen in hemochromatosis.

 

Explanation

 

Option B: Alcian blue: Alcian blue stains acidic polysaccharides and glycosaminoglycans in tissues blue, which is used to identify mucopolysaccharides. It is not used for iron staining.

 

Option C: Von Kossa: The Von Kossa stain is used to detect calcium salts, which appear black under microscopy. This would not be the appropriate stain for identifying iron deposits in the liver.

 

Option D: Crystal violet: Crystal violet is a basic dye that stains the components of cells purple or blue-violet and is often used in Gram staining of bacteria. It is not used for the detection of iron in tissue samples.

 

Educational Objective:

 

This stain is used to detect iron deposits in tissues and is characteristic of the pathology seen in hemochromatosis, where iron accumulation occurs within the hepatocytes.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 849

choices.text: Females do not increased incidence than males
Not associated with liver cirrhosis
Serum AFP levels are usually > 1000 mg/litre

questions.text: True about Fibrolamellar carcinoma of Liver is all, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serum AFP levels are usually > 1000 mg/liter

 

Option D:

 

Fibrolamellar carcinoma (FLC) of the liver is a rare variant of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) that has distinct clinical and pathological features.

 

Unlike typical hepatocellular carcinoma, fibrolamellar carcinoma is associated with normal or only mildly elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels. AFP levels are generally not as markedly elevated as in other types of hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Unlike conventional hepatocellular carcinoma, fibrolamellar carcinoma does not show a significant gender predilection. Both males and females are affected, and there is no clear male predominance.

 

Option B: Generally, fibrolamellar carcinoma is associated with a better prognosis compared to conventional hepatocellular carcinoma. It often occurs in younger individuals and is less likely to be associated with cirrhosis. Surgical resection is the primary treatment, and if the tumor is resected early, the prognosis can be relatively favorable.

 

Option C: Fibrolamellar carcinoma is characteristically not associated with liver cirrhosis. This is in contrast to conventional hepatocellular carcinoma, which is often linked to cirrhosis, especially in the setting of chronic liver diseases.

 

Educational objective:

 

AFP levels in fibrolamellar variant are generally not as markedly elevated as in other types of hepatocellular carcinoma

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 873

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic hepatitis B and cirrhosis presents with abdominal pain, unintentional weight loss, and fatigue. Imaging studies reveal a liver mass, and a biopsy confirms the diagnosis of the most common primary malignant tumor of the liver in adults. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatocellular carcinoma

 

Option C:

 

The most common primary malignant tumor of the liver in adults is hepatocellular carcinoma. HCC arises from hepatocytes and is closely associated with chronic liver diseases, particularly cirrhosis caused by viral hepatitis (hepatitis B and C), alcoholism, and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

 

HCC is the most common type of primary liver cancer in adults and often arises in the setting of chronic liver disease, such as cirrhosis from hepatitis B or C, alcohol abuse, or nonalcoholic fatty liver disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma is a type of cancer that usually arises in the skin or tissues that line the internal organs, but it is not typically found in the liver.

 

Option B: Hepatoblastoma: Hepatoblastoma is a rare malignant liver tumor that is most common in children, not adults.

 

Option D. Hemangioma: Cavernous hemangioma is the most common benign liver tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It is the most common primary malignant tumor of the liver in adults and is often associated with chronic liver disease such as hepatitis B-induced cirrhosis.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 870

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of jaundice and pruritus. Liver biopsy reveals characteristic "onion skin fibrosis" around the bile ducts. Laboratory tests show elevated alkaline phosphatase levels. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with the histological finding described?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primary sclerosing cholangitis

 

Option B:

 

"Onion skin fibrosis" refers to a characteristic histological finding in primary sclerosing cholangitis.

 

Primary sclerosing cholangitis is a chronic, progressive cholestatic liver disease characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Primary biliary cirrhosis is a distinct autoimmune liver disease characterized by the destruction of small bile ducts within the liver. "Onion skin fibrosis" is not a typical histological finding in primary biliary cirrhosis.

 

Option C: Extrahepatic biliary fibrosis: This term is nonspecific and not commonly used as a diagnosis.

 

Option D: Congenital hepatic fibrosis is a developmental disorder of the liver and is not associated with onion skin fibrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary sclerosing cholangitis is associated with characteristic "onion skin fibrosis" around bile ducts and elevated alkaline phosphatase levels, reflecting bile duct inflammation and fibrosis.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 861

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with painless jaundice, pruritus, and weight loss. Imaging studies reveal a nodular mass obstructing the bile ducts at the hepatic hilum. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of a Klatskin tumor. Which of the following best describes this tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nodular type of cholangiocarcinoma

 

Option A:

 

  • Cholangiocarcinomas are classified into intrahepatic and extrahepatic forms.

  • Eighty to 90% of the tumors are extrahepatic. The extrahepatic forms include perihilar tumors known as Klatskin tumors, which are located at the junction of the right and left hepatic ducts forming the com­mon hepatic duct, and distal bile duct tumors.

  • Most extrahepatic CCAs appear as firm, gray nodules within the bile duct wall

  • Klatskin tumors generally have slower growth than other CCAs, show prominent fibrosis, and infrequently involve distal metastases.

 

A Klatskin tumor is a type of cholangiocarcinoma that occurs at the hepatic hilum where the right and left hepatic ducts join. It is often nodular and can obstruct the bile ducts.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma: This is a distinct variant of hepatocellular carcinoma that typically affects younger individuals and has a characteristic appearance on imaging and histology, different from Klatskin tumors.

 

Option C: Gall bladder carcinoma:  Gall bladder carcinoma typically arises in the gall bladder itself and not in the bile ducts, hence it is not a Klatskin tumor.

 

Option D: Hepatocellular carcinoma: This is a primary liver cancer that originates from hepatocytes. A Klatskin tumor, however, arises from the biliary epithelium at the confluence of the left and right hepatic bile ducts.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Klatskin tumors are nodular cholangiocarcinomas located at the hepatic hilum and are known for causing biliary obstruction.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/871

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with fatigue, hepatomegaly, and neurological symptoms such as tremors and dysarthria. Ophthalmic examination reveals a brownish ring around the cornea. Laboratory tests show elevated urinary copper levels and decreased ceruloplasmin levels. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for the observed ophthalmic finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wilson’s disease

 

Option A:

 

"Kayser-Fleischer ring" is a brownish ring of copper deposits that can be observed in the cornea of the eye. This ring is a characteristic finding in Wilson's disease, an inherited disorder of copper metabolism.

 

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder of copper metabolism that leads to copper accumulation in various tissues, including the liver and brain. The Kayser-Fleischer ring, a brownish or greenish ring around the cornea due to copper deposition, is a hallmark of this condition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic condition that can lead to liver and lung disease due to the accumulation of abnormal alpha-1 antitrypsin protein in the hepatocytes. It does not cause the Kayser-Fleischer ring.

 

Option C: Hemochromatosis: Hemochromatosis is a hereditary condition characterized by excessive iron accumulation in various organs but does not lead to the formation of a Kayser-Fleischer ring.

 

Option D: Primary biliary cirrhosis: Primary biliary cirrhosis is an autoimmune liver disease characterized by the destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts. While it may lead to cirrhosis and associated symptoms, it does not cause the ophthalmic findings seen in Wilson’s disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a Kayser-Fleischer ring, neurological symptoms, elevated urinary copper levels, and decreased ceruloplasmin are all diagnostic of Wilson's disease, a disorder of copper metabolism.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /850
